title: "Open with Code" option missing from Windows context menu after reinstall

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
### **Bug Description**
After reinstalling Visual Studio Code and enabling both "Open with Code" context menu options during setup, the feature still does not appear when right-clicking a folder.
I have attempted several troubleshooting steps, including multiple reinstalls, but the "Open with Code" option remains unavailable in the context menu.

### **Steps to Reproduce**

Uninstall Visual Studio Code completely.

Download and install the latest VS Code version.

During installation, enable both "Add 'Open with Code' action to Windows Explorer file context menu" and "Add 'Open with Code' action to Windows Explorer directory context menu" options.

After installation, right-click any folder in File Explorer.

Expected Behavior
The context menu should display "Open with Code" for files and folders.

Actual Behavior
The option is missing from the right-click menu.


###** Environment**

VS Code Version: 1.103.0 (e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f, 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z)

OS Version: Windows 10 Pro x64 (10.0.19045)

CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-7200U CPU @ 2.50GHz (4 cores)

RAM: 8 GB

GPU: Enabled (WebGL, Vulkan disabled)

title: Formatting issue with JavaScript blocks in .blade.php file

labels.name: javascript
labels.description: JavaScript support issues

body:
Type: Bug Hello VS Code Team, I'm experiencing a formatting issue when working with Laravel Blade templates that include embedded JavaScript. Specifically, when using Blade syntax like {{ env('PUSHER_APP_KEY') }} inside a JavaScript string, the VS Code default formatter automatically breaks the string and adds unwanted spaces or line breaks. For example: 1) ``` const pusher = new Pusher('{{ env('PUSHER_APP_KEY') }}', { cluster: '{{ env('PUSHER_APP_CLUSTER') }}', encrypted: true }); ``` becomes: ``` const pusher = new Pusher('{{ env(' PUSHER_APP_KEY ') }}', { cluster: '{{ env(' PUSHER_APP_CLUSTER ') }}', encrypted: true }); ``` 2) `const logoutLink = document.querySelector('a[href="{{ route('logout') }}"]');` becomes ``` const logoutLink = document.querySelector('a[href="{{ route(' logout ') }}"]'); ``` and many more.. This breaks the Blade syntax and results in invalid JavaScript. It would be helpful if VS Code or the formatter could better handle embedded templating syntax (like Blade's {{ }}) inside JavaScript contexts, or allow better control to ignore formatting within certain blocks. Thank you for your great work and for considering this improvement! Best regards, Vinit VS Code version: Code 1.103.0 (e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f, 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Right-click menu option "Open with VS Code" missing after latest VS Code auto-update

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0 (user setup)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 1.0.26100
---
## **1. Problem Documentation**

**Title:**
Right-click menu option "Open with VS Code" missing after latest VS Code auto-update

**Description:**
Until this morning, when right-clicking on any folder in File Explorer, the context menu included an option **"Open with Code"** (or **"Open with VS Code"**).
After VS Code automatically updated to the latest release, this option is no longer available. This impacts workflow, as users now have to open VS Code manually and browse to the folder instead.

**Date/Time First Observed:**
08-Aug-2025 (Morning, after VS Code auto-update)

**Expected Behavior:**
Right-clicking any folder in File Explorer should display the **"Open with Code"** context menu option.

**Actual Behavior:**
After the latest update, the context menu entry is missing for all folders.

**Impact:**
Slower folder opening workflow; frequent manual navigation in VS Code.

---

## **2. Steps to Reproduce**

1. Update VS Code to the latest version (automatic or manual update).
2. Open Windows File Explorer.
3. Navigate to any folder.
4. Right-click on the folder.
5. Look for **"Open with Code"** option in the context menu.

**Result:** Option is not present.
**Expected:** Option should be available.

This was working as of yesterday, and broke immediately after the latest auto-update.

title: While focus is in chat window, backspace deletes in editor window
body:
Problem:

After I return to the vscode window from debugging my app, after an exception was thrown, I try to type text into the copilot chat window. I click in the chat window, and the text I type appears in the chat window properly. But the backspace and the cursor keys are only working in the code editor window. So it seems as if the focus was in two places at the same time, typing works in the chat window, backspace works in the code editor window. After I press Escape this problem goes away, and all keys start working properly where I put the focus.

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.30.0
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0
- Feature: agent mode
- Selected model: GPT 5
- Logs: (sorry, it is unclear where these are, and which logs you need)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I develop in C++, 
2. Debug-run the project until it throws an exception. 
3. I click in the chat window and start typing. The text I type appears in the chat window, but backspace, and cursor keys work in the editor window. So when I try to use backspace it appears as if it was not working, while it keeps deleting code from the editor, instead of deleting what I just typed in the chat window.
4. I press Escape a couple of times and click in the chat window again, the problem goes away.

title: fix(chat-editing): remove hardcoded 'Copilot Edits' from undo confirm…
body:
fixes : #260539

This PR fixes an issue where sourceLabel in the discard edits confirmation dialog could remain unused or cause type warnings because it was potentially undefined.
Added a default localize('agentEditsLabel', 'Agent Edits') fallback to guarantee a string type.
Updated localize calls in the confirmation message to ensure placeholders ({0}, {1}) match arguments.
Prevents red-highlight warnings in the editor and ensures correct label display for both single and multiple file scenarios.

title: GitHub Copilot: Azure language model provider not showing API key configuration UI

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

**Title:** GitHub Copilot: Azure language model provider not showing API key configuration UI

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No (requires GitHub Copilot extension)

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0-insider (user setup)
- OS Version: Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install GitHub Copilot extension
2. Open VS Code Insiders
3. Open Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P)
4. Run "GitHub Copilot: Manage Language Models" command
5. Select "Azure" from the provider dropdown list
6. Observe that no API key configuration UI appears

**Expected Behavior:**
- Azure provider should display a configuration interface to enter Azure OpenAI endpoint and API key
- Should be able to configure personal Azure OpenAI resources for use with GitHub Copilot
- Should work similar to other providers like OpenAI, Anthropic that show proper configuration UIs

**Actual Behavior:**
- No configuration UI appears when selecting Azure provider in Copilot's language model management
- Cannot enter API key or endpoint information for personal Azure OpenAI resources
- Other providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.) work correctly and show proper configuration interfaces
- Unable to use personal Azure OpenAI subscriptions with GitHub Copilot

**Additional Information:**
- This specifically affects GitHub Copilot's ability to use custom Azure OpenAI endpoints
- The Azure option appears in Copilot's language model provider list but lacks configuration capability
- No error messages are displayed
- Other language model providers in Copilot work as expected with proper configuration UIs
- This prevents users from using their own Azure OpenAI resources with GitHub Copilot

**Extension Information:**
- GitHub Copilot extension is installed and active
- Issue is specific to Copilot's language model management feature

**Environment Details:**
- Electron: 37.2.3
- Node.js: 22.17.0
- Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
- OS: Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS (Linux x64)

title: Task args are getting double-wrapped with quotes in v1.103.0

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: tasks
labels.description: Task system issues

labels.name: regression
labels.description: Something that used to work is now broken

labels.name: author-verification-requested
labels.description: Issues potentially verifiable by issue author

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No - VS Code Version: 1.103.0 - OS Version: Windows 10 Hello, everyone ! I'm a vscode extension developer. Recently, I have received feedback from some users that since they upgraded to version 1.103.0, the extended task execution function has not been working. When they rolled back to 1.102.0, the task execution function works. I have already done some checks. There are my code for task execution functions. ```ts const shellOption: vscode.ShellExecutionOptions = { env: process.env }; if (os.platform() == 'win32') { shellOption.executable = 'cmd.exe'; shellOption.shellArgs = ['/C']; commandLine = `"${commandLine}"`; } else { shellOption.executable = '/bin/bash'; shellOption.shellArgs = ['-c']; } // setup task const task = new vscode.Task({ type: 'shell', command: commandLine }, vscode.TaskScope.Workspace, title, 'eide.builder', new vscode.ShellExecution(commandLine, shellOption), []); task.group = vscode.TaskGroup.Build; task.isBackground = false; task.presentationOptions = { echo: true, focus: false, clear: true }; vscode.tasks.executeTask(task); ``` I have always wrapped cmd commands in quotation marks to ensure that cmd.exe can correctly parse the command line ```ts commandLine = `"${commandLine}"`; ``` It always been working properly. However, starting from version 1.103.0, vscode automatically added a pair of quotes to the command line, which led to extra quotes and thus broke the task execution feature. There is a screen shot. My extension will emit a command by vscode task like this: ``` cmd.exe /C "unify_builder -p d:\MyProgarm\xxx\builder.params" ``` However, what vscode actually performs is: ``` cmd.exe /C ""unify_builder -p d:\MyProgarm\xxx\builder.params"" ``` A pair of extra quotation marks caused this error. I checked the git commit of vscode between 1.102.0 ~ 1.103.0, and i found a related PR: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/251201 https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/251201/commits/33901866672b23c46095d14fd87b9f8aba8d53e7#diff-5d6d50fef79440567acc5f9a977c908f45f59342bb4d5e19ef5b9ee25e02920cR1235 Thanks.

title: Add "Mark Command as Finished" Option for Copilot Agent
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
When running commands via Copilot Agent (e.g., running tests or performing large code changes), there are situations where the command has actually completed, but the agent remains in a "running" state indefinitely. This appears to be a recurring issue where the agent does not detect the end of the process.

Currently, the only workaround is to wait for a timeout or manually restart the agent/session, which interrupts the workflow.

Proposed Solution:
Add a user-accessible option or command (e.g., "Mark Command as Finished") that can be triggered when the user knows the process has already completed.
This would:

Free the agent from the stuck "running" state.
Allow the next commands or prompts to proceed without restarting the session.
Improve workflow efficiency in long-running or misdetected tasks.
Example Use Cases:
Running a full test suite — output shows all tests have passed/failed, but the agent never detects completion.
Running large refactor operations — the task is visibly done, but Copilot stays in "thinking" mode.
Long shell commands — the process exits, but the Copilot Agent UI doesn’t update.
Possible Implementation Ideas:
A manual "stop" button specific to the current command (different from stopping the whole agent).
A quick command palette action (Copilot Agent: Mark Current Command as Finished).
Keyboard shortcut to trigger it.
Benefit:
This would give developers more control, reduce interruptions, and provide a practical workaround while the underlying detection bug is being addressed.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

Description:

After upgrading to VSCode 1.103.0, I've encountered a significant issue where the right-click context menu for files and folders no longer appears. It seems that the update causes the automatic removal of the associated registry entries for the right-click menu.

Steps to Reproduce:
Install VSCode 1.103.0 (either via the user setup or an update from a previous version).

After installation or update, right-click on a file or folder in File Explorer.

Notice that the "Open with VSCode" option (or similar context menu item) is missing.

Check the registry entries for right-click menus under HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\*\shell and HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Directory\shell, and find that the entries are deleted.

Expected Behavior:
The right-click menu for files and folders should remain intact after the update, with the "Open with VSCode" option present as before.

Actual Behavior:
The right-click menu item for VSCode is removed automatically after updating to 1.103.0.

The registry entries for VSCode in the paths:

HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\*\shell

HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Directory\shell

HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Drive\shell

are deleted or missing.

Additional Information:
Downgrading to previous versions (e.g., 1.102.x) resolves the issue, and the right-click menu functionality returns as expected.

The issue is only present in VSCode 1.103.0, and has not been observed in earlier versions.

Please look into this issue, as it impacts productivity and the expected behavior of VSCode.

title: Copilot Chat with Azure OpenAI models fails due to unsupported `temperature` parameter
body:
## Description
When using GitHub Copilot Chat with BYOK Azure OpenAI deployments for GPT-5 models (honestly, with any previous reasoning model, this has been an issue for months at this point), requests fail with a `400` error because the extension sends a `temperature` value of `0.1`. These models only support the default `temperature` of `1`, so any non-default value causes the API to reject the request.

## Steps to Reproduce
1. In `settings.json`, configure an Azure OpenAI model for Copilot Chat, for example:
   ```json
   "github.copilot.chat.azureModels": {
       "gpt-5": {
           "name": "gpt-5",
           "url": "https://<your-resource>.openai.azure.com/",
           "maxInputTokens": 100000,
           "maxOutputTokens": 100000
       }
   }
   ```
2. Open Copilot Chat and select the configured Azure model from the model dropdown.
3. Send any prompt.

## Expected Behavior
Copilot Chat should either:
- Not send the `temperature` parameter at all (let the model default to 1), or
- Allow the user to configure `temperature` in `settings.json` and set it to 1 for models that require it.

## Actual Behavior
The request fails with the following error:
```
Sorry, your request failed. Please try again. Request id: 7e0b7ba1-831b-4f5f-bcfd-48694ff772bb

Reason: Request Failed: 400 {
  "error": {
    "message": "Unsupported value: 'temperature' does not support 0.1 with this model. Only the default (1) value is supported.",
    "type": "invalid_request_error",
    "param": "temperature",
    "code": "unsupported_value"
  }
}
```

## Notes
- The `temperature` field is not a supported setting in `github.copilot.chat.azureModels`, so the user cannot override it.
- This appears to be hard-coded behavior in the Copilot Chat extension for certain model types.
- Reproduces consistently with `gpt-5`, `gpt-5-mini`, `gpt-5-nano`, and `gpt-5-chat` deployments in Azure.

## Proposed Fix
- Skip sending `temperature` in requests to Azure OpenAI models if it is not explicitly configured.
- Alternatively, allow `temperature` to be configured per model in `settings.json`.
- Detect models that only support `temperature=1` and set it accordingly.

title: Fix initialization timing issue in inline edits by ensuring tabAction observables never return undefined
body:
The `InlineEditsGutterIndicator` was experiencing a runtime error when `tabAction` was accessed during initialization before the model was fully set up.

**Error:**
```
TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'background')
at gutterIndicatorView.ts:342:62
```

**Root Cause:**
During initialization, derived observables that create `tabAction` in model classes could return `undefined` when accessing dependent observables that weren't fully ready. This occurred in two locations:

1. `GhostTextIndicator` in `inlineEditsModel.ts` - depends on `editorObs.isFocused` 
2. `InlineEditsViewAndDiffProducer` in `inlineEditsViewProducer.ts` - depends on `model.tabShouldJumpToInlineEdit` and `model.tabShouldAcceptInlineEdit`

When these dependencies threw exceptions or returned unexpected values during initialization timing edge cases, the derived observables could return `undefined` instead of a valid `InlineEditTabAction`.

**Fix:**
- Added try-catch blocks in both model creation locations to ensure derived `tabAction` observables always return valid `InlineEditTabAction` values, even during initialization edge cases
- Added nullish coalescing (`?? InlineEditTabAction.Inactive`) in the consuming code as a defensive safeguard

This addresses the root cause at the source rather than just masking symptoms, ensuring the observable contract is maintained throughout the initialization process.

Fixes #260066.

title: Question: Has VS Code observed the `JSON.stringify` performance boost in Chrome 138 after upgrading Electron?

labels.name: question-discussion
labels.description: Question that could be a discussion topic (experimental label)

body:
> Hello everyone, this question is directed to the VS Code team. I'm not sure if it's appropriate to ask it here as an issue—"Create Issue" seems to suggest that I should ask on StackOverflow instead. Unfortunately, however, this question did not pass the StackOverflow community review.

In Chrome 138, the V8 engine introduced [an optimization](https://v8.dev/blog/json-stringify) that significantly improves the performance of JSON.stringify in certain scenarios — in some cases, more than doubling the speed.

I noticed that VS Code v1.103 uses Electron37, which now uses Chromium 138 under the hood.

My question is:

Has the VS Code team observed this performance improvement in real-world usage? If so, in what scenarios or workflows is the JSON.stringify speed-up most noticeable?

title: Display token multiplier for models in manageModels view (same as model picker)

labels.name: feature-request

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->


Title: Display token multiplier for models in manageModels view (same as model picker)

Description:
In the new manageModels interface (accessible via the model selection dropdown in the inline chat UI), it would be very helpful to display the token multiplier next to each model — similar to how it's shown in the model picker (e.g., 1x, 0.33x, etc.).

Currently, in the "Manage Language Models" dialog, this information is missing, making it harder to make informed decisions about model cost/performance tradeoffs.

Why it's useful:

The token multiplier is a critical factor when choosing between models, especially for users conscious of performance vs. speed vs. cost.

This would bring consistency between the model selection dropdown and the model management modal.

Feature request:

Add token multiplier display next to each model in the manageModels UI.

Format: identical to how it appears in the main dropdown (see screenshot for reference).

title: "settingsSync.ignoredSettings" entries display as invalid if they're settings from disabled extensions
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- OS Version: Windows 11 24H2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Disable some extension (maybe a language support extension for a language you don't use often).
2. Open a workspace and enable the extension only for that workspace (maybe since it's a project in that language).
3. Add one of the extension's settings to `"settingsSync.ignoredSettings"` (maybe one for a path to a local executable).
4. Close the workspace.
5. Open your user `settings.json` now. A warning is displayed saying that `"settingsSync.ignoredSettings"`'s "value is not accepted", even though you have a perfectly good reason for it.

Technically, this might not be considered a bug, since it doesn't actually impair any usage. However, it is nonetheless unexpected behavior, and it mildly annoys me that my `settings.json` will forever be displayed with warnings just because VS Code happens to be presently unaware of one of the settings ignored from sync.

title: JAWS/NVDA is not announcing the real time content. It is reading some extra content along with the generated response:A11y_Visual Studio Code_Github_Copilot_Screen reader
body:
**Please do not close this bug. This bug should only be closed by Trusted Tester after verification.**
"[Check out Accessibility Insights!](https://nam06.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https://accessibilityinsights.io/&data=02%7c01%7cv-stfe%40microsoft.com%7cb67b2c4b646d4f9561a208d6f4b5c39b%7c72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7c1%7c0%7c636965458850501301&sdata=mxhokIKNMb22llsjXHLgU3XZibj1Qfx37rpY4PU2sfE%3D&reserved=0) - Identify accessibility bugs before check-in and make bug fixing faster and easier."

## GitHub Tags
#A11yeDAD; #A11yMAS; #A11yTCS; #Win32; #A11ySev3;#DesktopApp; #Visual Studio Code Client; #BM-VisualStudioCodeClient-Win32-Jan2024; #WCAG1.3.1; #FTP; #Screen Reader; #JAWS; #Element:chatboard; #STP; #NVDA;

## Environment Details:
Application: VS Code
Visual studio code version: 1.103.
OS: Windows 11 Enterprise 24H2
Build: 26100.2605
Screen reader
JAWS version: 2025
NVDA: 2024.4.2

## Repro Steps

1. Turn on Jaws/NVDA screen reader
2. Open Visual Studio Code 
3. Ensure GitHub Copilot is installed and signed in.
4. Open a Python file (e.g., app.py) or create a new one.
5. In the editor, provide a prompt that requires Copilot to generate a large or complex block of code. For example below prompt and observe the issue

"Generate a complete backend server in Python that includes:
- User authentication with JWT
- SQLite database integration
- RESTful endpoints for user CRUD operations
- Input validation
- Logging
- Error handling with appropriate HTTP status codes
- Configuration for CORS and environment variables"


## Actual Experience.
When Copilot is generating the code, screen reader is not announcing the real time content. It is reading some extra content along with the generated response.
Note: Issue is repro with NVDA

## Expected Experience
Screen reader should announce the real time content and it should not read extra content along with the generated response.

## User Impact:
Screen reader user face difficulty if screen reader will not announce the real time response and reading some extra content along with the generated response.

NVDA:

title: Display the repository name in the tooltip when hovering over the repository in the Source Control section

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

labels.name: scm
labels.description: General SCM compound issues

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

body: In the provided screenshot, the hover tooltip currently only shows the branch name only. The request is to have it display both the branch name and the repository name in the tooltop. This is particularly useful when working with multiple repositories within a single window, as it can be difficult to determine which repository is being viewed without expanding the left sidebar. Prior to update 1.103.0, this was not an issue because VS Code displayed both the trimmed branch name and repository name in the UI, and hovering over the repository UI would reveal the repository name. If this is planned, can we also add the option to toggle branch name trimming in status bar. Currently, it is like this, in my case trimming would save a lot of space in status bar.

title: Missing 'Open with Code' Context Menu Option in Latest VS Code Update (Windows)

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.103.0 - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open Windows File Explorer. 2. Right-click any file or folder. 3. Previously, "Open with Code" or "Open with VS Code" would appear in the context menu, but after the latest VS Code update, this option is missing. **I have already tried uninstalling and reinstalling VS Code, but the context menu option is still missing.** **Expected Behavior** The right-click context menu should show the "Open with Code" or "Open with VS Code" option, as it did before. **Actual Behavior** This option has completely disappeared after the update. Because of this, I am unable to open files or folders directly in VS Code from the context menu. **Additional Information** I checked with all extensions disabled—the problem remains same. I have not yet tried the Insiders build. I have observed the same issue on multiple machines. **[Reddit thread with multiple users reporting the same issue]**(https://www.reddit.com/r/vscode/comments/1mkc3t9/open_with_code_disappeared_from_my_windows_11/) **_Please let me know if you need logs or any other diagnostic information; I can provide them if required._**
